items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Bridlington has been issued. Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of high tides. Overtopping waves are expected during high tide this morning, Tuesday 8th March 2022, between 09:15am and 11:15am, then again on this evenings high tide between 9:00pm and 11:30pm. The areas of particular concern are around Bridlington South Pier and the Lifeboat Station. Please be careful along all beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths, and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further significant rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the River Thame following rainfall last week. Roads and farmland may still hold flood water especially close to the river around Stadhampton. A few rain showers are forecast this afternoon (Tuesday 8th) followed by a dry night. River levels are slowly decreasing however we expect them to remain high over the next couple of days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this afternoon unless the situation changes.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are slowly falling but remain high at the Welney Causeway river gauge following last week’s rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Tuesday 08/03/2022. We expect flooding to affect the Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to continue to fall slowly throughout today, Tuesday 08/03/22. This information is correct as of 07:40 on Monday 08 March. The causeway at Welney has approximately 1 centimetre of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. Flood water is receding from the causeway at Sutton Gault. Due to uneven surface of the road, water may be deeper in places. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 16:00 this afternoon, 08/03/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. No further rainfall is forecast. Flood water is receding from the causeway at Sutton Gault. Due to the uneven surface of the road deep puddles may be encountered.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels are slowly falling but remain high at the Welney Causeway river gauge following last week’s rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Tuesday 08/03/2022.  We expect flooding to affect the A1101 Wash Road at Welney.   No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to continue to fall slowly throughout today, Tuesday 08/03/22. This information is correct as of 07:40 on Tuesday 08 March. The causeway at Welney has approximately 1 centimetre of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road. This alert applies to WELNEY CAUSEWAY ONLY. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated by 16:00 this afternoon, 08/03/2022, or as the situation changes.
